displayed_text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: -but the Aliguard’s okay right? Patient: Aliguard is okay. I'm tired. Yeah, but it doesn’t totally destabilize my life. Doctor: Right, right. I think when you get off the Xtandi, you're actually gonna feel a little bit better. Because you know, at four pills a day does weigh on you. So I think that would be better. But I'm gonna talk to S____, our research nurse who's covering for M____ who's our regular research nurse. But S___ will come in here and will just go over and see how you feel about it. You know if you're interested, great. We'll move forward and do what we need to do. We have to check to make sure all these lovely things can stay on and if not, we do regular chemo. Family Member: Well, it makes me feel good is one big concern. I get is that if he starts getting so much bone loss he can't function and his quality of life and if you can zap areas at which I didn't know. Yeah, it makes me realize hey he can have a quality of life. Doctor: Oh yeah that's number one. Family Member: There you go S___. Doctor: Living is very important but we can't do it with you laid up in bed doing nothing and just say well it's good we got the prostate cancer all taken care of. Family Member: Right that’s not good. Doctor: I say that all the time too. Patient: The one on my ribs doesn't bother me. Doctor: It doesn’t bother you. Patient: That doesn’t bother me. The one that frightens me is the one’s going up and down my spine.

Healthcare Professional: This is the one you take in the morning and at night. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So - that’s why I said if I give you the Percocet it’s going to lower your dose of OxyContin. Patient: Okay, okay. Doctor: But if that works for you I’m good with that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If it doesn’t work we’ll have to go back to the other OxyContin. Patient: Original. Okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because that’s what you asked for. Patient: Right.

Patient: Um hum. How do you feel about it? She wanted to end all this crazy stuff. Family Member: I don’t think it’s crazy stuff. (Laughter) Doctor: Yeah. I get, you know, I think in the trials that they did with these drugs, and these are now not even new anymore They’re sort of old now. We’ve been doing this a long time. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, they did trials in men before chemotherapy and after chemotherapy. It’s kind of the dividing line. And in both cases, they saw that the men responded very well, and that it improved survival of the men. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Now, the survival part’s tricky because that’s the whole group, and some of the men, so, you look at the number total, it’s only, you know, a couple of months’ difference between the guys that get the drug and the guys that don’t. But within that group, there are some people that respond really well and really long who probably are getting much more than a couple of months, and there’s some people where it doesn’t do anything, and they’re probably getting nothing out of it. So, uh, the other thing they look at in the trials is something called a, sort of a risk reduction. So there’s pretty significant reduction in dying from prostate cancer if you’re on, if you take the drug. So in my experience, what I’ve seen is about a third of the men I give the drug to, their PSA drops, and they have a really long response that usually long means somewhere between, well, I’ve only been using it, you know, a couple of years now, but two to three years sometimes. Family Member: Um hum. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: One, one to three years, maybe, let’s say. Uh, another third of the guys, the PSA drops really nicely, and then starts to go back up usually six months or so, and then the third group of guys, usually the PSA is a readout. It just marches along. In your case, that’s going to be the primary thing for us because the bone, like I said, it’s hard to measure changes. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So, uh, and the, the biggest fact from the drug was in men before chemotherapy, it’s probably just because they were earlier in their disease-

Patient: Yeah. Hum, that, but I call R___ about, huh, that. Oh. I don’t know. That , it ran out. They sent it seven days too early, and there’s no refills. That’s what I’m saying about, starting seven days early, but I still need them, and I need Doctor: That kind of stuff I can help you with uh if you need a refill, um. Patient: Okay. When I take the ibuprofen, then I might only have to take one of the morphine. You know what I’m saying? More during the day, if the pain coming back just take the ibuprofen and I won’t need morphine. (Coughs) Doctor: So I have a known history, and your hepatitis C, they treated it. Right? Patient: No. It’s in, not, huh, you know how you, huh, you go get this medicine for it? They say I’m not in that category to get anything for it. Doctor: Okay. So your, your hepatitis C isn’t serious and hasn’t, huh, caused any-? Patient: Right. Doctor: Okay. That may be the biggest, huh, roadblock. It says have a known history of hepatitis C infection. Huh, it is one of the things that would make it so that you can’t do the style, the study. I can still give you the chemo, huh, but it may be that you’re not eligible for the trial because of that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Some of that we just have to check with the study team, huh, to see that this is up to date, huh, or not. I don’t have a paperclip. I’m going to check before you head out to see if I can get one for you. Huh, but again, we’ll have to see whether this one makes sense for you or not because of the hep C stuff. It doesn’t mean I can’t give you the chemo. It may be from a trial thing, you’re not allowed to do it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And we also, the other thing you might need a blood transfusion to become eligible, huh, so we’ll have to keep an eye on that one too, if we had to do that. Huh, so let’s go over your medicines. So you said that, huh, your ibuprofen was written on February nineteenth. You have no refills. Patient: Right.

Family Member: Shoot me now! Patient: I’m just wondering about a younger woman. Doctor: OH GOD! Family Member: OH! Doctor: Yeah, why don’t you find that one first, and - Patient: I guess I can cross that off my list (chuckles) Doctor: Yeah, I think. Patient: Oh did you get a new car yet? Doctor: I did. UNISON OH! Healthcare Professional: Oh you got a new car? Family Member: Oh no, you’re kidding. Doctor: Well I did because my daughter has taken mine. So I badly needed one. I mean I needed a set of wheels for sure.

Healthcare Professional: Just let me know when you’re done and I’ll come turn it off. Doctor: Okay, great. Thank you. Okay. Patient: Alrighty. Doctor: Okay. All right. So first we have to go over results. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So you have the CAT scan- Patient: Mhm. Doctor: -that showed probably no evidence of metastatic disease, okay, meaning no evidence of cancer that we can see. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: The reason why I say probably- did you get these results on MyChart? Patient: Nuh-uh. Doctor: Okay, are you are you on MyChart? Family Member: We are, but we didn’t go on there.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So I think, I think, again, what’s the best way to go? I mean the groups in Germany have way more experience doing this. Family Member: Um hum. Um hum. Doctor: Uh but you know it’s more complicated because you’ve got to go to Germany and all that, all those, there’s, there’s a layer to it. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Although you know saying that, you still would have to go away from home. Patient: To go to Cornell. Doctor: Cornell or UCLA, so, yeah. Patient: Well, I guess I would ask you, if possible, to check out both avenues. I’d want to see which one. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I mean my interest, our interest, is just to stop this stuff from growing. It seems to be growing at a consistent pace. I don’t know if it’s slow, fast, or whatever, but it’s not stopping. And do you think that this, this sort of, from what you know from this, from the, you know PSMA, that would have a real uh opportunity to stop the growth? Doctor: Yeah. I think from the data they published, it actually looks really good, uh, and-

Patient: Okay.That’s yours Okay and this is Doctor: That is a problem as is the … ORIOLE trial. Patient: Okay. And, this is for me? Doctor: That is your copy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: As is this diagram Patient: Okay. Doctor: Do you have any other questions that arise immediately that you want to discuss? Patient: Uh, and you may not be able to are you gonna be able to check when Doctor: Yeah so that’s a good question. So um there’s an easy answer to that and there’s a more easy answer to that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: The easy answer is if you ever develop symptoms from your cancer. For example, if the cancer has spread to your bone or if the cancer in the lymph node causing a blood obstruction. stop the

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the last 2 years (1 year but less: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the last 2 years (1 year but less than 2 years ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.None: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::None

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.disagree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::disagree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.strongly agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::strongly agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.strongly agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::strongly agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.strongly agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::strongly agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.strongly agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::strongly agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: I, I don’t know enough about either drug in terms of the side effect profile. I, I know the one where you get one or the other has been pretty well tolerated. Uh, and the other drug is, uh, I haven’t put anybody on the trial yet, so I don’t have the experience, but, uh, I know from our meetings, I haven’t heard any signal that says this is horribly toxic. So, uh, so I, I think side effect wise, I don’t think that we’re going to have that much problem. It’s really just a matter of can we-? Family Member: So they saw a lot of more spots on his bone from the last, uh-? Doctor: Yeah. Let me, uh, pull that up. So- (pause14sec) Patient: Um hum. (Laughter) Doctor: Uh, right. (Sound Door closes) Family Member: It’s too bad they haven’t came up with something more with the bones whereas they can, you know? Doctor: Well. Family Member: Interact with- Doctor: There’s been a lot of- (Sound Door opens) Family Member: Oh, no. Doctor: Spine and ribs and shoulders. Family Member: Spine, ribs, and shoulder? (pause11sec)

Patient: No, no. Now, I’m saying uh, uh. Doctor: Did it start two days ago from today? Patient: Yeah! Doctor: But I didn’t give you the chemo. Patient: I know! Doctor: Yeah. Patient: That’s what I’m sayin’. So, Doctor: Yes. So, maybe it’s something Patient: That’s all, so what it does, is that a fact, can it happen like that? Can they do that? Like, is it, like I had diarrhea before, Doctor: Yeah. Are you taking any laxative or a stool softener or anything? Patient: Yeah. That’s what I’m sayin’ to you that stool softener don’t Doctor: Stop that then, because that’s, uh, worsening your diarrhea.

Family Member: And now I have a question, and you can tell me if you know how to answer this but you know you’re saying here you’re giving us all our options. Is your heart in one place and the other with standard of care two versus the chemo and super hormone for somebody like him? Doctor: Sure. I’m a too. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So I’m an ah aggressive guy. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Um you’re a young guy. You don’t want to look back. Or if it was me, Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: I would say I wouldn’t want to look back and not do everything I could have done. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: We might not cure you, but I think psychologically, you know I’ve done everything I can. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: But that you know, people feel differently. The only thing I say is you know to people is you really, really do have to do the radiation and the hormones. Family Member: Um hum.

Patient: Mhm. Doctor: -and then decide if you know you're even eligible, or that you're even interested after you review it one more time. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then if it's good, then they sign you and then we go, and if you're like eh I don’t know, and then we think of something else. No pressure. Okay. Patient: Okay. Doctor: All right. Patient: All right. So this is the best. This is the best option that you're thinking right now. Doctor: Mhm. Yeah. It keeps you on things that you haven't really broken through, but your pills are starting to do this. They’re starting to tread water. And I'm like, “Hold up!” before you start to sink. Let me see if we can throw a lifeline. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So a lot of the prostate cancer trials are like that now. So we're like, I'm okay. I'm okay. And then you’re like uh oh I’m starting to fade. And so we have all these new pills that are like, wait- Patient: Mhm. Doctor: - I'm gonna come and help you. Patient: Okay, so.

Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: - have not had it as an issue. Family Member: Everybody has their issues. Doctor: It is. So every time you read that consent form it’s like you opened up a bottle of Motrin, took out the little package insert, (HCP laughing) Family Member: You know even one person Doctor: Um hum. FAM - who’s on the study said oh I had seizures – Healthcare Professional: You have to write it down. Doctor: You’re absolutely right. Yep. But I think you know whether you’re on this study or not as we talked about in the past, you, that pill is something that is a standard of care. Like I would give that whether you make it on this study or whether you choose to be on this study. Family Member: Got it. Doctor: So that’s the good part. Family Member: Now this has been approved? Doctor: Yeah. Yes. That one is approved. Healthcare Professional: The Xtandi, yes.

Healthcare Professional: You didn’t tell me your were throwing up, you told me you was just having diarrhea. Patient: No I told you I throwed up three times. Doctor: When was the last time? Patient: Same time I was having diarrhea. Doctor: Okay. Alright. Patient: I threw up times. I have Doctor: I think we should refer him to GI because I really don’t know what uh… Patient: What? Doctor: I have no idea. I’ve never seen that. Patient: Yeah me either. Doctor: And we can’t see it on the CAT scan either. So I don’t know what to make of it. Patient: What?

Family Member: Right. Doctor: Okay? Okay, let me see if she’s around so I can just give you a time frame um and uh thanks for bringing this in. This is very helpful. Patient: Good. Um hum. Family Member: We were happy when the results came in. Doctor: Yeah, no genes . Okay, great, good to see you. Family Member: Okay, thanks. Doctor: Happy holiday if I don’t see you before then. Patient: Happy holiday to you.
